pullRequest.body:
The division by 0 affected #20521: all `ofNat` debts were removed in that PR, so one denominator became 0 giving a [CI error](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12636151506/job/35207580913).

This PR fixes the issue.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

No declarations were harmed in the making of this PR! üêô
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
```

</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by grunweg.

:v: adomani can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12656452643/job/35269025013)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12656452643/job/35269025274)

Good catch!
I don't speak fluent awk (somebody please double-check the syntax etc.), but the change broadly looks good to me. I have one or two questions.
maintainer delegate?

Is $3 a shell positional argument (or, e.g., some awk local variable)?
In the former case, please
- document the expected argument to the script in the top-level comment,
- give it a default value (as the script uses `set -u` at the top)

In the latter case... perhaps this is fine. Or a comment, for the confused non-awk-experts like me, is helpful: up to you.

`$3` is the "field number" that `awk` uses: in this case, `awk` is splitting the input using `|` as a field separator, so it reads a line, and calls each substring contained between consecutive `|` with an increasing index.  So, `$3` is what happens in
```bash
not here| neither here| yes, here!|not anymore...
```

The input of `awk` is (basically) `report` that has
```bash
|Current number|Change|Type|
```
as header, so `$3` really means whatever happens in `Change`.

~~I'll add~~ I added a "general" comment to what the fields represent at the `awk` call, rather than here where the variable is used.
Ah, makes sense! Thanks a lot for explaining!
I also am just looking at the awk manual while reviewing this, but is there a reason to compare with "0" rather than just 0 here?

I *think* that the two (`total == 0` and `total == "0"`) and probably equivalent, but I also think that `awk` has a slight preference for coercing numbers to strings.  This makes me suspect that comparing `total` to the *string* `0` is a little more robust than comparing it to the number `0`.

In this case, since `total` started out being a number, it probably does not make a difference, though.

OK, thanks! I think since `total` should only ever be a number, the quotes here are probably introducing an unncessary coercion, which was confusing at least to me, so let's just get rid of them:
```suggestion
          if (total == 0) {average=absWeight} else {average=weight/total}
```

bors d+

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - fix(scripts/technical-debt-metric): avoid division by 0
